| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | [monst.c#line2149](/wiki/Monst.c#line2149 "Monst.c") |

A **human zombie**, Z, is a type of monster that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [zombified](/wiki/Zombie "Zombie") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") that can [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") [you](/wiki/You "You") to other levels if it is adjacent.

A human zombie has a single claw attack.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [4.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated human zombies may occur in small [groups](/wiki/Group "Group") of 2 to 4, and are always created hostile.

The human zombie is the first [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") monster for [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), and make up 96⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Priest quest](/wiki/Priest_quest "Priest quest"). Several human zombies are also generated on various floors of the Priest quest at level creation: twelve are generated on the home level, two are generated on each of the upper filler levels, three are generated on the lower filler levels, and sixteen are generated on the goal level. The Priest quest also has several undead-filled graveyards that include human zombies among their ranks. Human zombies may additionally appear among the zombies and other monsters that are part of the first quest monster class for the branch, and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

One human zombie is generated to the left of [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus") within [his lair](/wiki/Orcus-town "Orcus-town") at level creation, and three more are randomly placed across the level.

[Guards](/wiki/Guard "Guard"), [high priests](/wiki/High_priest "High priest"), [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"), and [Angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel") are special-cased to become human zombies if the player attempts to animate their [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") by any means, including [statue traps](/wiki/Statue_trap "Statue trap") and directly creating them in [wizard mode](/wiki/Wizard_mode "Wizard mode").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) While [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") are also listed among these monsters, this only applies to wizard mode creation since revival is special-cased to work on them.

A human zombie will leave an aged [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster\) "Human (monster)") corpse upon death.[\[2\]](#cite_note-undead_to_corpse-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-make_corpse-3)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Human monsters that are killed by a zombie or [lich](/wiki/Lich_\(monster_class\) "Lich (monster class)") may revive as a human zombie.

## Strategy

Human zombies have a decently strong claw attack, making groups of them dangerous for early characters who are careless or caught unprepared. Chaotic [human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)") characters can use these zombies to convert cross-aligned altars with their corpses, or else summon peaceful [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON") on co-aligned ones.

## History

The human zombie first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), where the various zombies are first distinguished from each other. The ["zombie" monster](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster\) "Zombie (monster)") that is present in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, and appears from [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0") to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"), has essentially the same statline as the human zombie in later versions.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), human zombies can be created by using the [raise zombies](/wiki/Raise_zombies "Raise zombies") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") while adjacent to the corpse of any [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)").

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), human zombies are replaced with the [zombie](/wiki/Zombie_\(GruntHack\) "Zombie (GruntHack)") [racial monster](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster"), which humans are eligible to generate as - the monster shares the same stats as the human zombie of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Any non-undead human monster killed by a zombie will rise as a human zombie.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), most zombies are a form of [derived undead](/wiki/Derived_undead "Derived undead") that have a template applied to a living monster (e.g. a "xorn zombie"), rather than distinct monsters as in *NetHack* - human zombies can be created this way, either via random generation or animation from a regular human corpse. A basic ["zombie" monster](/wiki/Zombie_\(monster\)#dNetHack "Zombie (monster)") that is near-identical to the human zombie in *NetHack* serves roughly the same purpose, i.e. a fallback for attempts to create guards, high priests, aligned priests, and Angels in wizard mode, though it can also appear randomly on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level").

Three of the six rooms on the lower filler level(s) of the [Binder quest](/wiki/Binder_quest "Binder quest") each contain a human zombie at level creation, and fifteen human zombies are generated within the goal level of the [Pirate quest](/wiki/Pirate_quest "Pirate quest") at level creation.

## Encyclopedia entry

The zombi ... is a soulless human corpse, still dead, but taken from the grave and endowed by sorcery with a mechanical semblance of life, -- it is a dead body which is made to walk and act and move as if it were alive.

\[ W. B. Seabrook ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2415](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/read.c#L2415)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-undead_to_corpse_2-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L147): *Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-make_corpse_3-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L372): *Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops*

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Attacks Claw 1d8
Z human zombie
Difficulty 5
Attacks

Claw 1d8

Base level 4
Base experience 41
Speed 6
Base AC 8
Base MR 0
Alignment -3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 200
Size Medium
Resistances Cold, sleep, poison
Resistances conveyed None

A human zombie:

  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is undead.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can follow you to other levels.
  • has infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
  • can leave an old human corpse.
Reference monst.c#line2149

A human zombie, Z, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It is a zombified human that can follow you to other levels if it is adjacent.

A human zombie has a single claw attack.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 GruntHack
    • 4.3 dNetHack
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Randomly generated human zombies may occur in small groups of 2 to 4, and are always created hostile.

The human zombie is the first quest monster for Priests, and make up 96⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the Priest quest. Several human zombies are also generated on various floors of the Priest quest at level creation: twelve are generated on the home level, two are generated on each of the upper filler levels, three are generated on the lower filler levels, and sixteen are generated on the goal level. The Priest quest also has several undead-filled graveyards that include human zombies among their ranks. Human zombies may additionally appear among the zombies and other monsters that are part of the first quest monster class for the branch, and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated there.

One human zombie is generated to the left of Orcus within his lair at level creation, and three more are randomly placed across the level.

Guards, high priests, aligned priests, and Angels are special-cased to become human zombies if the player attempts to animate their corpse or statue by any means, including statue traps and directly creating them in wizard mode.[1] While shopkeepers are also listed among these monsters, this only applies to wizard mode creation since revival is special-cased to work on them.

A human zombie will leave an aged human corpse upon death.[2][3]

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Human monsters that are killed by a zombie or lich may revive as a human zombie.

Strategy

Human zombies have a decently strong claw attack, making groups of them dangerous for early characters who are careless or caught unprepared. Chaotic human characters can use these zombies to convert cross-aligned altars with their corpses, or else summon peaceful demons on co-aligned ones.

History

The human zombie first appears in NetHack 3.0.0, where the various zombies are first distinguished from each other. The "zombie" monster that is present in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, and appears from Hack 1.0 to NetHack 2.3e, has essentially the same statline as the human zombie in later versions.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, human zombies can be created by using the raise zombies technique while adjacent to the corpse of any human.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, human zombies are replaced with the zombie racial monster, which humans are eligible to generate as - the monster shares the same stats as the human zombie of NetHack. Any non-undead human monster killed by a zombie will rise as a human zombie.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, most zombies are a form of derived undead that have a template applied to a living monster (e.g. a "xorn zombie"), rather than distinct monsters as in NetHack - human zombies can be created this way, either via random generation or animation from a regular human corpse. A basic "zombie" monster that is near-identical to the human zombie in NetHack serves roughly the same purpose, i.e. a fallback for attempts to create guards, high priests, aligned priests, and Angels in wizard mode, though it can also appear randomly on the Rogue level.

Three of the six rooms on the lower filler level(s) of the Binder quest each contain a human zombie at level creation, and fifteen human zombies are generated within the goal level of the Pirate quest at level creation.

Encyclopedia entry

The zombi ... is a soulless human corpse, still dead, but taken from the grave and endowed by sorcery with a mechanical semblance of life, -- it is a dead body which is made to walk and act and move as if it were alive.

[ W. B. Seabrook ]

References

  1. ↑ src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2415
  2. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147: Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts
  3. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372: Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops

A '''human zombie''', {{monsym|human zombie}}, is a type of monster that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a [[Zombie|zombified]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] that can [[follow]] [[you]] to other levels if it is adjacent.

A human zombie has a single claw attack.

==Generation==
Randomly generated human zombies may occur in small [[group]]s of 2 to 4, and are always created hostile.

The human zombie is the first [[quest]] monster for [[Priest]]s, and make up {{frac|96|175}} of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [[Priest quest]]. Several human zombies are also generated on various floors of the Priest quest at level creation: twelve are generated on the home level, two are generated on each of the upper filler levels, three are generated on the lower filler levels, and sixteen are generated on the goal level. The Priest quest also has several undead-filled graveyards that include human zombies among their ranks. Human zombies may additionally appear among the zombies and other monsters that are part of the first quest monster class for the branch, and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated there.

One human zombie is generated to the left of [[Orcus]] within [[Orcus-town|his lair]] at level creation, and three more are randomly placed across the level.

[[Guard]]s, [[high priest]]s, [[aligned priest]]s, and [[Angel]]s are special-cased to become human zombies if the player attempts to animate their [[corpse]] or [[statue]] by any means, including [[statue trap]]s and directly creating them in [[wizard mode]].{{refsrc|src/read.c|2415|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} While [[shopkeeper]]s are also listed among these monsters, this only applies to wizard mode creation since revival is special-cased to work on them.

A human zombie will leave an aged [[Human (monster)|human]] corpse upon death.{{refsrc|src/mon.c|147|nethack=3.6.7|name="undead_to_corpse"|comment=Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts}}{{refsrc|src/mon.c|372|nethack=3.6.7|name="make_corpse"|comment=Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops}}

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Human monsters that are killed by a zombie or [[Lich (monster class)|lich]] may revive as a human zombie.}}

==Strategy==
Human zombies have a decently strong claw attack, making groups of them dangerous for early characters who are careless or caught unprepared. Chaotic [[Human (starting race)|human]] characters can use these zombies to convert cross-aligned altars with their corpses, or else summon peaceful [[M2_DEMON|demons]] on co-aligned ones.

==History==
The human zombie first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]], where the various zombies are first distinguished from each other. The [[Zombie (monster)|"zombie" monster]] that is present in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, and appears from [[Hack 1.0]] to [[NetHack 2.3e]], has essentially the same statline as the human zombie in later versions.

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], human zombies can be created by using the [[raise zombies]] [[technique]] while adjacent to the corpse of any [[Human (monster attribute)|human]].

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], human zombies are replaced with the [[Zombie (GruntHack)|zombie]] [[racial monster]], which humans are eligible to generate as - the monster shares the same stats as the human zombie of ''[[NetHack]]''. Any non-undead human monster killed by a zombie will rise as a human zombie. 

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], most zombies are a form of [[derived undead]] that have a template applied to a living monster (e.g. a "xorn zombie"), rather than distinct monsters as in ''NetHack'' - human zombies can be created this way, either via random generation or animation from a regular human corpse. A basic [[Zombie (monster)#dNetHack|"zombie" monster]] that is near-identical to the human zombie in ''NetHack'' serves roughly the same purpose, i.e. a fallback for attempts to create guards, high priests, aligned priests, and Angels in wizard mode, though it can also appear randomly on the [[Rogue level]].

Three of the six rooms on the lower filler level(s) of the [[Binder quest]] each contain a human zombie at level creation, and fifteen human zombies are generated within the goal level of the [[Pirate quest]] at level creation.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|The zombi ... is a soulless human corpse, still dead, but taken from the grave and endowed by sorcery with a mechanical semblance of life, -- it is a dead body which is made to walk and act and move as if it were alive.
|[ W. B. Seabrook ]
}}
